Graphical abstract MOFs have emerged as battery materials that significantly enhance the energy density, cycle life, and safety of LIBs. This review focuses on the application of MOFs in advanced LIB materials, encompassing electrode materials, separators, electrolytes, coating layers, and additives. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are among the most promising materials for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) owing to their high surface area, periodic porosity, adjustable pore size, and controllable chemical composition. For instance, their unique porous structures promote electrolyte penetration, ions transport, and make them ideal for battery separators. Regulating the chemical composition of MOF can introduce more active sites for electrochemical reactions. Therefore, MOFs and their related composites have been extensively and thoroughly explored for LIBs. However, the reported reviews solely include the applications of MOFs in the electrode materials of LIBs and rarely involve other aspects. A systematic review of the application of MOFs in LIBs is essential for understanding the mechanism of MOFs and better designing related MOFs battery materials. This review systematically evaluates the latest developments in pristine MOFs and MOF composites for LIB applications, including MOFs as the main materials (anode, cathode, separators, and electrolytes) to auxiliary materials (coating layers and additives for electrodes). Furthermore, the synthesis, modification methods, challenges, and prospects for the application of MOFs in LIBs are discussed. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Electrodes Electrolytes Separators Lithium-ion batteries 1 Introduction Fossil fuels are a finite resource and they cause severe environmental problems such as global warming. Therefore, energy and the environment are significant issues that must be addressed, and the development of new energy sources is an important area of research [1]. Solar and wind energy have great potential for electricity generation. However, they are intermittent and there are large variations in the amount of electricity that can be generated. Therefore, effective energy storage and conversion devices are required to provide a reliable energy supply [2]. Among emerging energy storage systems, electrical energy storage systems may be the most effective [3]. In particular, batteries, such as lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) [4], sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) [5], lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) [6], and lithium-air batteries (LOBs) [7], are among the most advanced energy storage systems [8]. LIBs have attracted widespread attention owing to their high energy density, excellent cycling stability, and environmentally friendly properties. Currently, the main cathode and anode materials in commercially available LIBs are LiCoO2 and graphite, respectively. The working principles of these LIBs are shown in Scheme 1 a. As LIBs are charged and discharged, Li ions move between the positive and negative electrodes through the separator, and an equal number of electrons flow back through the external circuit. The electrode materials used in LIBs can be divided into three categories according to their Li-storage mechanisms: insertion-type materials (including graphite and titania), conversion-type materials (such as metal oxides, sulfides, phosphates, and nitrides), and alloying-type materials (such as Si, Ge, Sn, and P), as shown in Scheme 1(b). Insertion-type materials have good stability during charging and discharging; however, they have low specific capacities. By contrast, conversion- and alloying-type electrode materials have poor stability owing to the large volume changes that occur during charging and discharging; however, they have high specific capacities. The widespread adoption of electric vehicles and large-scale energy storage systems has increased the demand for high-performance energy-storage devices [9]. To meet this demand, novel materials with high power densities, high energy densities, long operating lives, high charging rates, and low costs are required for the next generation of LIB technologies. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are two- or three-dimensional (2D or 3D) porous materials comprised of metal nodes and organic ligands connected by coordination bonds [10,11]. MOFs can have different structures and functions depending on the combination of organic ligands and metal centers. So far, over 80 000 MOFs have been explored and applied across various fields [10], such as gas storage/separation [12], catalysis [13], energy storage [14,15] and drug delivery [16]. Theoretical calculations and experimental tests have shown that the choice of metal sites and organic ligands in MOFs has a significant effect on the electrochemical performance [17,18]. Compared to traditional porous battery materials, MOFs benefit from the following advantages: high specific surface areas [18], good designability [19], and adjustable molecular-level periodic porosity [18,20] and excellent tailorability [20]. Consequently, MOFs can provide unexpected breakthroughs in the field of energy storage (Scheme 2 ). For example, compared to the low surface area of traditional porous electrode materials such as graphite [21] and lithium titanate [22], MOFs are more porous, adjustable at the molecular-level, and have an extremely high specific surface area [19]. This facilitates the contact between the electrode and the electrolyte, and improves the charge transport at the interface. Furthermore, compared to emerging covalent organic frameworks (COFs), there are more MOFs owing to the variety of metal ions or metal clusters that can be introduced, and the metal centers with unsaturated coordination provide infinite possibilities for LIBs applications. The unsaturated coordination sites, often referred to as open metal sites, are present in the metal centers of MOFs. These sites possess empty orbitals and can coordinate with other ions that have lone electron pairs. Moreover, MOFs are easier to synthesize than COFs. In short, MOF-based materials encountered in lithium-ion batteries will promote our deeper understanding of LIBs. The intrinsically porous structures, controllable chemical composition and open metal sites (OMSs) of MOFs are key properties for electrochemical energy storage. The porous structures of MOFs facilitate the electrolyte penetration and ion transport, giving MOFs a huge advantage in the field of batteries separators [23,24] and electrolytes [25–29]. The controllable chemical components of MOFs allow more electrochemically active sites to be introduced, which provides unlimited possibilities for different battery systems [30–32]. Finally, the OMSs in the MOFs can be used to improve the migration number of lithium ions by fixing the anions on the OMSs of MOFs, thereby increasing the conduction rate of lithium ions in the MOFs-based solid electrolytes [30–32]. However, MOFs have inherently poor electronic conductivity and structural damage may occur during the charging and discharging processes, which has hindered their development as the electrode materials. Nonetheless, their poor electronic conductivity (extremely important), ease of modification, and porous structures have made them promising for use as electrolytes and separators. MOFs are brittle, unstable, and expensive to synthesize. Therefore, it is necessary to use advanced methods to design MOFs with ideal electrochemical behaviors. Moreover, the electrochemical performances of MOFs can be improved by introducing other nanomaterials, such as conductive carbon materials [23,33,34], electroconductive polymer [35], and other functional materials [27,36] to form MOFs composites. Overall, the development of pristine MOFs and MOF composites for electrochemical energy storage is an interdisciplinary field with opportunities and challenges. Therefore, a systematic and comprehensive review of MOFs in the field of LIBs is required to improve our understanding of the underlying mechanisms and to guide the design of MOF-based battery materials. Previous works have considered the applications of MOFs in LIBs. However, they have mainly focused on MOFs as electrode materials, and they have rarely considered other applications. Therefore, this review considers the wider applications of pristine MOFs and MOF composites in LIBs, including their use as the primary materials (anodes, cathodes, separators, and electrolytes) and auxiliary materials (electrode coatings and electrode additives). The ways in which MOF-based materials can be used in LIBs are summarized in Scheme 3 . The electrochemical properties of MOFs as electrode materials and their mechanisms of actions as electrolytes, separators, coatings, and additives are summarized in the Supporting Information (Tables S1, S2, and S3). MOF derivatives obtained via pyrolysis are not considered here, as there are many good reviews and research articles on this topic [37–45]. Although we acknowledge the strengths of MOFs and MOF composites in LIBs, we also highlight the current challenges and potential solutions to provide a balanced overview of the current situation. 2 Synthesis of MOFs The morphology and particle size of electrode materials can significantly affect the performance of LIBs. Moreover, the methods and conditions used to synthesize MOFs also have a notable impact on the morphology and size of the MOFs [46]. In this regard, we provide a brief overview of the commonly used synthesis methods of MOFs reported in the current literatures, which can be divided into solvochemical, microwave-assisted, mechanochemical (e.g., ball milling), and electrochemical methods [47], as illustrated in Scheme 4 . 2.1 Solvochemical methods In solvochemical methods, a homogeneous mixture containing a predetermined ratio of a metal salt, organic ligand, and solvent is poured into a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)-lined stainless-steel vessel, heated to the required temperature, and held for a certain time. The MOFs synthesized via solvochemical methods have small grain defects, small and uniform particles, and good particle dispersion [47,48]. However, this method is usually energy-intensive and time-consuming. 2.2 Microwave-assisted methods Microwave-assisted methods rely on the interplay between Hertzian waves and reactants with moving charges. These reactants can be liquids that contain polar molecules or solids that conduct ions. In contrast to traditional solvothermal methods, microwave-assisted methods do not heat the solution through the container. Instead, the microwaves work directly on the reactions, which reduces the reaction time, thereby reducing the fabrication time. The MOFs synthesized via microwave-assisted methods also contain smaller particles than those synthesized via solvochemical methods [49]. The microwave method has requirements for the reaction material. The material is a poor conductor of heat, which is prone to uneven heating. Additionally, the heating temperature is difficult to control, and heating too fast is prone to excessive heating. 2.3 Mechanochemical methods Mechanochemical methods do not require the addition of a solvent, or they use only small amounts of solvent. Instead, they rely on mechanical forces to carry out the reactions, which makes them difficult to control the reactions rate. However, due to the simple preparation processes and environmentally friendly characteristics, the methods have gained wide attention and application [50]. 2.4 Electrochemical methods The electrochemical techniques used to prepare MOFs consist of two methods: anode dissolution and cathode deposition. During the anodic dissolution process, metal ions are released from the electrode via the applied potential, which react with organic linkers to form MOFs. During the cathode deposition process, MOFs are deposited by an increase in pH near the cathode surface, where organic linkers, metal ions and alkali solutions come into contact with the cathode surface, leading to electrochemical reduction of alkali [51]. However, the yield of this method is low and by-products are easy to appear. 3 Applications of pristine MOFs and MOF composites in LIBs 3.1 Anode materials Commercial graphite anodes are widely used in many fields such as electrical vehicles and consumer electronics [52,53]. However, the theoretical specific capacity of graphite is only 372 mA h g−1, based on the reversible insertion and exudation of Li ions in its structure. This significantly limits the development of LIBs [52,53]. Hence, considerable efforts have been made to identify new anode materials with high specific capacities, long battery lives, environmentally friendly properties, and low costs [54–57]. MOF-based electrode materials can be divided into two groups according to the Li-storage mechanism, that is, into conversion- and insertion-type materials. Conversion-type materials undergo conversion reactions where the transition metal ions on the MOF nodes are reduced to zero-valent metals and the ligands combine with Li to form organic Li salts. If the metal can form an alloy with Li (e.g., Zn), the subsequent discharge reaction will be followed by an alloying reaction. The structure of the MOF is destroyed in the first conversion reaction and the subsequent electrochemical reaction may involve Li-insertion and removal processes with the metal and organic Li salt. In insertion-type materials, Li ions are intercalated and deintercalated from the pores of the MOF without destroying its structure. The first MOF electrodes used in LIBs were fabricated using MOF-177, which was first reported as an anode material in 2006 [30]. In MOF-177, Li ions are inserted via conversion and alloying reactions. MOF-177 has an initial discharge capacity of 400 mA h g−1 at 50 mA g−1. However, this decreases to 105 mA h g−1 for the second cycle owing to the irreversible destruction of its structure. Despite the poor electrochemical performance of MOFs, next-generation electrode materials with better electrochemical performances have been developed. Theoretically, MOF electrodes with high specific capacities may be achieved by reducing the relative molecular weight and increasing the number of Li-storage sites. Therefore, it is necessary to select suitable ligands for use in MOFs with high specific capacities. An approximately constant discharge specific capacity of 560 mA h g−1 was maintained over 60 cycles at 60 mA g−1 for voltages of 0.005–3.0 V. There are two reasons why MOFs that use formic acid as the ligand have higher specific capacities and greater cycling stability than MOF-177. First, the metal formates have lower molecular weights, which increases the specific capacity. Second, HCOOLi is formed during the discharge process instead of Li2O, which increases the cycling stability. The Li-storage mechanisms of the metal formates and MOF-177 are identical. However, the structural changes that occur in the metal formates are reversible, which greatly improves the long-term cyclability of the materials. The metal formates may show electrochemical reversibility because it is more feasible to convert lithium formate (CHLiO2) into transition metal formates than to convert lithium oxide (Li2O) into transition metal oxides [58]. The electrochemical Li-storage process of Mn-LCP occurs via a reversible conversion-type mechanism, where metallic Mn and organic Li salts are produced after discharge to 0.01 V. From the fourth cycle, the Mn-LCP electrode has a discharge specific capacity of 390 mA h g−1. In addition to decreasing the molecular weight of MOFs, increasing the number of Li-storage sites can also increase the theoretical specific capacity of MOFs. Several strategies to improve the electrochemical properties of MOFs have been reported in the literature: (1) increasing the conductivity of the MOFs, (2) preparing nanoscale MOFs, (3) introducing units with multielectron redox properties, (4) using thermal activation to liberate the channels in the MOFs, and (5) using MOF glass. 3.1.1 Increasing the conductivity of MOFs Conductivity significantly affects the electrochemical properties of electrode materials and two methods of increasing the conductivity of MOFs have been reported. First, the conductivity of the MOFs themselves can be increased. Second, the MOFs can be combined with conductive constituents. In 2019, Yuan et al. used conductive Cu3HHTP2 nanowires as anodes in LIBs [60]. Cu-based MOFs have high electrochemical conductivities, large pore sizes, and 1D channels. Therefore, the Cu3HHTP2 nanowires demonstrated a remarkable discharge capacity of 630 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1. Moreover, when the current density increased tenfold, their discharge capacity remained higher than the specific capacity of graphite [60]. In 2021, 2D conductive MOF Cu-HHTQ [61] (HHTQ = 2,3,7,8,12,13-hexahydroxytricycloquinazoline) was synthesized as a negative electrode material for LIBs. The ligand TQ (tricycloquinazoline) used for the synthesis of this MOF was first shown to be electrochemically active, and the CuO4 unit (which is also electrochemically active) was constructed into a 2D conductive MOF, greatly facilitating the transport of Li+ and e−. In addition, 2D conductive Cu-HATN (HATN = hexaazatriphenylene) [62] was synthesized for use as a aonde material for Li-ion batteries, which also exhibited high specific capacity and excellent Li-ion transport kinetics. The above two kinds of 2D conductive MOFs are constructed by using electrochemical organic electrode materials and electrochemically active CuO4 units, and the combination of the two plays the role of 1 + 1 > 2, which is described as follows: (1) organic electrode materials that are easily soluble in organic electrolytes coordinate with CuO4 to generate MOFs, inhibiting ligand dissolution and enhancing cycling stability; (2) Organic electrodes with poor conductivity and CuO4 generate 2D conductive MOFs, while improving the charge transfer kinetics of organic ligands and metal centers. Ionic doping is considered to be an effective means of increasing the conductivity of electrode materials by introducing defects into nanoscale electrode materials. Similarly, doping MOFs with metal ions to synthesize bimetallic MOFs (BMOFs) is a valid means of improving their conductivity. In 2016, Hu et al. used a hydrothermal method to prepare MnCo-benzene 1,3,5-tricarboxylate (BTC) with a low cobalt content [63]. The Co-doped Mn-BTC exhibited a higher discharge capacity than that without Co doping, which may be because Co doping improved the conductivity of the Mn-BTC. Other examples of BMOFs include ZnFe-MOFs [64] and Co- and Zn-coordination polymers [65]. BMOFs exhibit better electrochemical properties than their monometallic counterparts, and further investigation is required to understand the underlying mechanisms. More methods (such as extended conjugation and redox hopping) to improve the self-conductivity of MOFs can refer to professional reports [66,67]. In addition, the conductivity of MOFs can be improved by combining them with other conductive materials, such as carbon materials [68], metal foams [63], and conductive polymers [69]. Yu et al. reported a light concentration-assisted heterogeneous nucleation method that could be used to prepare MOF/reduced graphene oxide (rGO) composites (Fig. 1 a) [68]. This method can also be used to synthesize other MOFs/rGO materials, such as Ni-ZIF, Co, Fe-ZIF, Co, and Cu-ZIF. For convenience, we considered Co-ZIF@rGO-F (where F refers to the 3D foam-like hierarchical architecture shown in Fig. 1b) as an example. Co-ZIF nanosheet and Co-ZIF@rGO-P (where P indicates that Co-ZIF nanosheets were attached in parallel to rGO) samples were fabricated to compare their electrochemical performance. The results (Fig. 1c) indicate that the Co-ZIF@rGO-F-25 and Co-ZIF@rGO-P had high conductivity, which substantially increased the Li-storage capacity compared to pure Co-ZIF nanosheets. Similarly, anode materials such as Ni-NDC/SWCNT [69] (Fig. 2 a), Fe-MOF/RGO [70] (Fig. 2b), MIL-53/rGO [71], Al-MOF/Graphene [72] (Fig. 2c), Co-MOF/rGO [73], NF-MOF@MXene [74], Ca-MOF/Graphite [75], PB/Graphene foam [76], MOF-74/Ni foam [77] (Fig. 2d) have shown excellent Li-storage performance owing to their enhanced electrical conductivity compared to the individual MOFs. 3.1.2 Preparation of nanoscale MOFs Nanotechnology can be used to significantly improve the electrochemical performance of electrode materials. Nanomaterials offer several advantages over bulk materials. First, they provide more Li-storage sites because the contact area between the electrode material and the electrolyte is larger. Second, their smaller size effectively reduces the absolute tension during the deintercalation and intercalation of Li ions. Third, they offer shorter diffusion distances for Li ions and electrons in the active materials. Nanoscale MOFs can also be synthesized by regulating the synthesis conditions and they deliver better electrochemical properties than their bulk counterparts, as explained above. In recent years, 0D MOF nanoparticles, 1D MOF nanowires or nanorods, 2D MOF nanoflakes/sheets, and 3D MOF micro-nanostructures have been considered as LIB electrode materials. For example, a nanoscale Fe-BTC MOF (with nanoparticles 200 nm in diameter) was synthesized using a suitable Fe source in water at room temperature (∼25 °C). The nanoscale Fe-MOF exhibited a specific discharge capacity of 1022 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 mA g−1. Moreover, when the current was increased five-fold, the specific discharge capacity remained at 436 mA h g−1 after 400 cycles. By comparison, microscale Fe-MOFs have a Li-storage capacity of just 300 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.5 mA g−1 [78]. This indicates that reducing the size of the MOFs to the nanoscale improves the performance. To investigate the effects of morphology on the electrochemical properties of nanoscale MOFs, the same research group prepared Co-coordination polymers (CPs) with different morphologies, including s-CoHNta (nanosphere), r-CoHNta (nanorod) and w-CoHNta (nanowires), by regulating the reaction conditions (Fig. 3 a) [79]. Electrochemical tests showed that r-CoHNta had a discharge specific capacity of 875 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles at 500 mA g−1. This greatly exceeds the specific capacities of s-CoHNta (609 mA h g−1) and w-CoHNta (165 mA h g−1). A similar trend was observed for rate cycling (Fig. 3b). This may be because the 1D nanorods/wires were longer and narrower than the other morphologies, which reduced the diffusion distance of Li+ and e− in the active materials during charging and discharging and prevented agglomeration. By contrast, the surface energy of the nanospheres was high, and they were prone to aggregation, which resulted in low specific capacity and cycling stability. In addition, Mn-BTC nanorods [80], Fe-terephthalic acid (BDC) nanorods [81], Co-MOF nanowires [82] and ultrathin Co-MOF sheets [83] (Fig. 3c) and other MOF-based nanomaterials have also been developed as advanced anode materials in LIBs. Nanoscale MOFs have demonstrated better rate performances and specific capacities than their bulk counterparts. However, nanomaterials also have some drawbacks. For example, they easily agglomerate during charging and discharging owing to their high surface energies and activities, which causes capacity degradation during cycling [79,84]. Therefore, it is difficult to fully exploit the advantages of nanomaterials for use in LIBs. One solution to this is to construct 3D micro-nano structures composed of low-dimensional nanoscale units. These structures combine the advantages of the ultra-large specific surface areas of nanomaterials and the weak activities of micro-nano structures, and they have demonstrated desirable properties for use as electrode materials in LIBs [85]. For example, Ni-BTC MOFs with various morphologies have been prepared by simply changing the composition of the solvent by Gan and co-works (Fig. 4 a and b) [86]. Among the synthesized Ni-BTCDMF (smooth microsphere), Ni-BTCDMF/EtOH (corrugated microsphere), and Ni-BTCEtOH (hierarchical mesoporous microsphere) three materials, the hierarchical porous Ni-BTCEtOH MOF with a floral morphology exhibited the best electrochemical properties. During the first cycle, Ni-BTCEtOH delivered a discharge capacity 1913 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1 and higher than Ni-BTCDMF (1780 mA h g−1), and Ni-BTCDMF/EtOH (1800 mA h g−1). After 100 cycles, discharge specific capacities of 1085, 667 and 519 mA h g−1 are achieved for Ni-BTCEtOH, Ni-BTCDMF/EtOH and Ni-BTCDMF, respectively. Among the three Ni-MOFs, Ni-BTCEtOH exhibited the highest initial CE and required the least time to stabilize at 200 mA g−1, which demonstrates the exceptional Li-storage properties of the Ni-BTCEtOH MOF electrode (micro-nanostructure) (Fig. 4c). The micro/nanostructure provided a way for electrons to connect and reduced the diffusion distance for Li ions (Fig. 4d). Meanwhile, the large surface area of Ni-BTCEtOH MOF ensured that there was contact between the active material and the electrolyte. Other MOFs with micro-nanostructure have also been developed for use as anodes in LIBs, such as a seashell-like Co-based MOF with a hierarchical layered structure [87] and a Co-2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic coordination polymer (TFBTC)with a lamellar secondary structure (Fig. 4c and d) [88]. The limitations of nanomaterials can also be overcome by combining them with conductive materials. For example, researchers prepared MOFs less than 5 nm in diameter using coated polypyrrole (PPy) bulk Co-MOF particles/graphene composites as precursors and then encased them in N-doped carbon/graphene (NC/G) using a confined thermal pulverization strategy and coated polypyrrole (PPy) bulk Co-MOF particles/graphene composites as precursors (Fig. 5 a). The resulting sub-5 nm MOF@NC/G demonstrated a reversible discharge capacity of 1301 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 [89]. When the current density was increased by a factor of forty, the specific capacity remained at 494 mA h g−1. The cycling stability at an ultra-high current density of 10 A g−1 was also investigated. The sub-5 nm MOF@NC/G composites anodes exhibited outstanding cycling stability, with a 98.6 % capacity retention after 2000 cycles. The excellent electrochemical performance of the sub-5 nm MOF@NC/G composites was attributed to two factors. First, the ultra-small MOF nanoparticles with a high surface area increased the contact area between the electrolyte and the active material. Second, the N-doped carbon coating effectively inhibited the agglomeration of MOF nanoparticles and provided sufficient accessible sites and void spaces for Li-ion storage and volume changes (Fig. 5b and c) [89]. Researchers have also considered other MOF/conductive-material composites such as rGO/Fe-BTC (graphene immobilizes Fe-MOF nanoparticles) [64] and Ni foam/MOF-74 (Ni foam immobilizes Ni-MOF nanorods) [76], for use as anode materials in LIBs. In each case, the electrochemical performance of the MOF composites was better than that of the single-component MOFs. 3.1.3 Introducing units with multi-electron redox properties MOFs are composed of metal ions and organic ligands connected via coordination bonds. If the Li-storage sites in the MOFs are only provided by metal cations or organic ligands, then the theoretical specific capacity of the MOFs may be low. The number of Li ions that can be stored per unit can be significantly increased by using transition metals and organic ligands with both types of redox-active sites to construct the MOFs. Alternatively, the specific capacity can be improved by using metals or ligands that contain multiple Li-storage sites to construct the MOFs. For example, Hu et al. prepared Mn-based MOFs with coexisting redox activities in the metal units and organic ligands for use as an anode material in energy-dense Li-storage applications (Fig. 6 a) [90]. Above 0.5 V, the metal Mn ions in the Mn-based MOFs were mainly reduced to metal Mn. Below 0.5 V, the coordinated oxygen atoms and benzene rings with delocalized π electrons in the ligand were reduced by the intercalated Li ions (Fig. 6b). The Mn-based MOF anodes exhibited a superior reversible discharge specific capacity of 1187 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. Moreover, when the current density increased by a factor of 20, the capacity remained at 701 mA h g−1. In the same study, Ni-MOFs were prepared with the same chemical structures. However, the Ni-MOFs exhibited poor electrochemical performance compared to Mn-MOFs (Fig. 6c). This was attributed to the fact that the Mn-MOFs were thinner and had a larger surface area than the Ni-MOFs, and the fact that the Mn ions were smaller than the Ni ions. MOFs can also increase the number of Li-storage sites via chemical activation. For example, Wang et al. constructed a coordination-induced molecular cross-bonding COF/Mn-MOF composite for use as the anode in LIBs. The COF/Mn-MOF composite delivered a discharge capacity of 1015 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1 after 650 cycles, which was higher than that of Mn-MOF (258 mA h g−1) without the hybridization. This performance was derived from the activated Mn centers and aromatic benzene owing to molecular-level coordination which increased the number of Li-storage sites [91]. The molecular-level hybridization activated the MOFs and increased the number of redox centers. Therefore, this approach may be used to establish an advanced program to improve the Li-storage performance of MOFs used as electrode materials for LIBs. Polyoxometalates (POMs) with multielectron redox-active systems can also be used to construct MOFs with improved capacity for use as LIB electrode materials. POMs with attractive structures, various oxygen-containing functional groups, and multielectron redox active sites exhibit excellent Li-storage performance [92]. For example, [PMo12O40], known as an “electron sponge,” delivers an ultra-high specific capacity when used as the anode material in LIBs owing to the multi-electron oxidation–reduction reaction with Li+. However, some POMs are highly soluble in electrolytes, which hinders their application in LIBs [92]. When MOFs with POMs as the central nodes (POMOFs) are used as anode materials in LIBs, they exhibit highly reversible capacities and excellent cycling stabilities. This may be because the POMs and organic ligands form a 3D frame of coordination bonds, which effectively inhibits the dissolution of POMs into the electrolyte. Moreover, the POMOFs have a 3D periodic porous structure, which effectively increases the contact area with the electrolyte and acts as a buffer against volume changes. 3.1.4 Thermal activation to liberate the channels in the MOFs Traditional intercalated electrode materials store Li ions between the layers, thereby releasing electrical energy. By contrast, insertion-type MOF electrode materials store Li ions in their porous structures. Notably, occluded inactive molecules (such as H2O and other solvents) inside the channels of MOFs can prevent the smooth intercalation and deintercalation of Li ions. Moreover, blocked channels hinder the diffusion of Li ions. Therefore, the unoccupied channels can be used to improve the electrochemical properties of MOFs. Hu et al. prepared Mn-based MOFs (Mn-BDC) and obtained a sample labeled Mn-BDC@200 by removing the coordinated solvents from the porous structure of the MOF at 200 °C [93]. The capacity of Mn-BDC@200 showed greater reversibility than that of Mn-BDC. After 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1, Mn-BDC@200 and Mn-BDC retained discharge specific capacities of 974 and 725 mA h g−1, respectively. By contrast, Lin et al. prepared ultra-stable Zn-based MOFs with a specific surface area of 821 m2/g for use as an anode material in LIBs [94]. When the inner pores of the Zn-based MOFs were partially blocked using polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA), the specific capacity was very low compared to the unblocked Zn-based MOFs. These examples show that a porous structure can greatly improve the specific capacities of insertion-type anode materials. 3.1.5 Using MOF glass Yue et al. produced ZIF-62 glass by melt-quenching, as shown in Fig. 7 (a) [95]. In comparison to crystalline ZIF-62 created using conventional methods, the ZIF-62 glass exhibited superior electrochemical behavior, as shown in Fig. 7(b). After 1000 cycles at 2 A g−1, the discharge specific capacity of the ZIF-62 glass anode was 306 mA h g−1, whereas that of the crystal ZIF-62 was just 188 mA h g−1. Notably, the capacities of the ZIF-62 glass and crystalline ZIF-62 both increased over the course of a cycle; however, the increase was larger for ZIF-62 glass. This was attributed to the repeated movement of Li ions in and out of the ZIF-62, which partially destroyed its coordination bonds. This generated more defects and channels, which increased the number of Li-storage sites and facilitated Li ion migration, as shown in Fig. 7(c). 3.2 Cathode materials To the best of our knowledge, the Li-storage mechanisms of MOF cathodes in LIBs are all insertion-type mechanisms. The literature indicates that there has been less research into MOF-based cathodes than anodes. The majority of MOFs designed for use as cathodes have used high-valence metal ions (such as Fe3+ and V4+) and organic ligands with or without redox activity. There have also been some efforts to improve the specific capacities of MOF-based cathodes. Férey et al. conducted the first investigations into MOF-based cathodes for LIBs [96]. They showed that an Fe-based MOF (MIL-53), [FeIII(OH)0.8F0.2(O2CC6H4CO2)], had a discharge capacity of 70 mA h g−1 (inserted 0.6Li ions per formula unit) at C/40 rates of 1.5–3.5 V (Fig. 8 a). The discharge capacity of MIL-53(Fe) was low owing to the limited number of intercalated Li ions per MOF. When the number of intercalated Li ions per MIL-53(Fe) unit is greater than 0.6, a non-reversible change in the structure may occur. Therefore, the instability of the MIL-53(Fe) structure was the main reason for the low Li storage. These irreversible reactions may be avoided by utilizing MOFs based on farther-ahead (3d) transition metals to take advantage of their lower orbital occupancies (higher oxidation states) and stronger M−O bond strengths relative to the changes in the charge of the electrode material [96]. For example, Jacobson et al. prepared VIV(O)(BDC) (MIL-47) for use as a LIB cathode [97]. The MIL-47 delivered a higher discharge capacity than isostructural MIL-53(Fe) because more Li ions were stored per MIL-47 unit. Moreover, the higher V-O bond strength of MIL-47 relative to the charge changes during the Li removal and insertion processes may have positively affected the discharge specific capacity. In addition to improving the stability of coordination bonds to increase the Li-storage capacity of MOFs, organic molecules with Li-storage capacity can be added to the holes in MOFs to provide extra Li-storage sites. For example, Combarieu et al. prepared a hybrid material (MIL-53(Fe)_quinone1) by loading MIL-53(Fe) with 1,4-benzoquinone (at a molar ratio of 1:1) via π-π interactions between the 1,4-quinone compounds and the benzene rings of the MIL-53 ligands (Fig. 8b) [98]. Compared to 1,4-benzoquinone, the MIL-53(Fe)_quinone1 composite exhibited a higher discharge specific capacity and a lower capacity decay rate, which indicates that benzoquinone can improve the specific capacity of composite materials and that MOFs can inhibit the capacity attenuation of 1,4-benzoquinone. However, the discharge specific capacity of MIL-53(Fe)_quinone1 was faster than that of MIL-53 alone. This indicates that the interactions between the MOFs and 1,4-benzoquinone molecules were not strong enough to stabilize the benzoquinone molecules. Consequently, some benzoquinone molecules dissolved in the electrolyte, which caused capacity attenuation. Therefore, stronger chemical interactions may be required to inhibit the dissolution of benzoquinone molecules and their analogs into the electrolyte. In 2014, Awaga et al. utilized a benzoquinone analog (2,7-anthraquinonedicarboxylic acid = 2,7-H2AQDC) as the ligand in a MOF. The coordination bond between the metal ions and 2,7-AQDC significantly reduced the solubility of 2,7-AQDC (Fig. 8c) [32]. Cu(2,7-AQDC) achieved an initial specific capacity of 147 mA h g−1, which decreased to approximately 105 mA h g−1 after 50 cycles at 4–1.7 V. Although the specific capacity and cycling stability of Cu(2,7-AQDC) improved to some extent, after 50 cycles, the retained Coulombic efficiency was only 70% owing to the highly localized electron density and limited electrical conductivity of the MOF [32,99]. In another study, the same researchers proposed a bipolar charging mechanism that could be used to improve the specific capacity and Coulombic efficiency of MOFs (Fig. 8d). Bipolar charging means that two Li ions are inserted during a single discharge reaction and three electrons can be released (with one originating from the PF6 − extracted from the MOF). This can greatly improve the specific capacity, reduce the ion transport traffic, and accelerate the diffusion of Li ions. The MOF with the bipolar charging mechanism exhibited an initial specific capacity of 205 mA h g−1 and 93% of the first cycle capacity was retained after 50 cycles [99]. In 2019, Chen et al. synthesized a 2D Cu-THQ MOF (Fig. 8e) [100], which also exhibited a bipolar charging mechanism. However, the MOF used a ligand with a smaller molecular weight and it had better conductivity; therefore, the specific capacity was unprecedentedly high for a LIB cathode material. Cu-THQ also achieved a large capacity of 387 mA h g−1 at 50 mA g−1 and retained a reversible capacity of 340 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. This is the highest specific capacity of a MOF cathode to date. In Section 3.1, we discussed the fact that the morphology of an MOF can significantly affect the electrochemical properties of the anode. The same is true for cathodes. In 2023, Winter et al. synthesized Cu-based 2D MOFs with nanorod (Fig. 9 a) and nanosheet (Fig. 9b) morphologies to investigate the effects of morphology on the electrochemical performance [101]. The results indicate that, compared to rod-like MOFs, flake-like MOFs have a higher specific surface area and more Li-ion transport pathways (Fig. 9c), which can effectively improve the Li-ion transport kinetics. In addition to organic molecules containing carbonyl groups, electrochemically active organic disulfides [102], triphenylamine-based organic molecules [103] and tetrathiafulvalene tetracarboxylate (TTF-TC) acid [104] can also be used as organic ligands to synthesize MOFs with improved capacity. For example, MOFs and CPs containing disulfide linkages have been synthesized using 4,4′-dipyridyl disulfide (4dpds), 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid (6dtna) and 2,2′-dithiobenzoic acid (2dtba) [104], which have Li-storage sites on the ligands. Electrochemical tests have shown that porous MOFs containing disulfide-ligand (DSMOFs) have much larger capacities than nonporous coordination polymers with disulfide ligands (DSCPs). This indicates that a porous structure is extremely important for the insertion-type MOF cathode materials, which is consistent with the aforementioned insertion-type MOFs anode materials described above. 3.3 Separators and electrolytes Due to their inherently poor electrical conductivity, MOFs may face some challenges when used as electrode materials. However, this property is beneficial when using MOFs as separators or electrolytes. Moreover, unlike traditional separators and electrolytes, MOFs have useful characteristics such as tunable porosities, high pore volumes, controllable molecular-level morphologies, and OMSs. 3.3.1 MOFs as separators Recently, Lu and co-workers fabricated a novel MOF-based composite separator (EMP) through electrospinning technology. The separator was connected to UIO-66 and PVA, which contained carboxyl and hydroxyl groups, respectively, via an esterification reaction (Fig. 10 a and b) [24]. When implemented in LIBs, the EMP significantly improved the electrochemical performances, particularly the rate performance and cycling stability (Fig. 10c). At 0.1 C (1 C = 170 mA g−1), the discharge specific capacities of the NCM|graphite full batteries (NCM = LiNi0.33Co0.33Mn0.33O2, cathode; graphite, anode; LP = LiPF6, electrolyte) with polypropylene (PP) and EMP were approximately equal. When the current density increased twenty times, the remaining capacity of the full NCM|graphite battery with EMP was 74% of the original value, which was higher than that of the NCM|graphite batteries using PP, which was 63%. The cycling stability was also evaluated at 1 C after the first five cycles at 0.2 C. The full NCM|graphite battery with EMP retained 73% of its first-cycle discharge capacity after 1000 cycles, whereas that with PP retained only 25% of its initial discharge capacity. The electrochemical characterization of a lithium iron phosphate (LFP)|LTO cell produced similar results. EMP separators containing MOFs with OMSs effectively absorb anions, thereby increasing the Li-ion transference number (0.79) and Li-ion conductivity, which is necessary to achieve superior rate capabilities. Moreover, EMP separators that contain MOF particles can mitigate the decomposition of electrolytes to form more stable interfaces between electrodes and electrolytes, which can improve cycling stability [24]. To produce high-power Li-ion batteries, MOFs with the unsaturated sites have been used to design separators with high-rate capabilities. Furthermore, the cage-confinement effect of MOFs has also been utilized to achieve high output voltage, which is necessary to increase the power density of LIBs. It is well known that the power density of a battery is linearly dependent on its output voltage. However, traditional liquid electrolytes are prone to decomposition under high-voltage conditions, which limits the cycling stability and results in poor Coulombic efficiency. Therefore, hybrid electrolyte systems consisting of dual electrolytes, that is, a catholyte and an anolyte segregated by a separator, have been developed [105]. In these systems, the cathodic and anodic redox reactions occur separately in their respective electrolyte environments without affecting each other. Therefore, the separator is an important feature of hybrid electrolyte systems because it prevents the electrolytes from interacting, and MOFs are often used as separator materials [106]. Owing to the specific pore windows of MOFs, MOF-based diaphragms can also be used to isolate dual electrolytes, where they act as a molecular sieve to prevent them from mixing. For example, Zhou et al. constructed a high-voltage Li-ion full cell using a two-component electrolyte, an ionic liquid (Li/Pyr13TFSI) catholyte and an equimolar LiTFSI/G3 complex anolyte, that was segregated using a separator composed of HKUST-1 (Fig. 11 a) [106]. The HKUST-1 separator had a small pore window and it acted as a sieve to prevent Pyr13+ and solvated [Li(G3)]+ from shuttling between the catholyte and anolyte (Fig. 11b). Scanning electron microscope (SEM) and optical images of the prepared separator are shown in Fig. 11(c). These results show that MOF-based separators can considerably improve the cycling stabilities of high-voltage LIBs with hybrid electrolyte systems. 3.3.2 MOFs as electrolytes Achieving fast and orderly conduction of lithium ions is the key to solid-state lithium-ion batteries. Traditional solid-state electrolytes, due to their low room temperature ion conductivity and Li+ migration number, seriously hinder the development of solid-state batteries. MOFs have high specific surface area, periodic porosity, and abundant OMSs, which provide the possibility of rapid and directed Li+ migration. The conductivity of MOF-based solid electrolytes reported so far can reach the order of 10−5–10−3 S/cm. In 2020, Lu et al. used UIO-66 to prepare gel polymer electrolytes (GPL) [107]. UIO-66 has OMSs; therefore, the electrolyte had liquid-ion-like conductivity. Moreover, the GPL electrolyte is safer for use in LIBs than traditional liquid electrolytes. Other MOFs have been used as electrolytes in Li-metal batteries. Owing to their high theoretical capacity (approximately ten times the theoretical capacity of graphite) and highly negative redox potentials, Li-metal anodes have attracted considerable interest. However, the dendritic growth of Li produces an unstable solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) and large volume changes occur during cycling, which are major safety concerns. Recently, progress has been made in the development of safe Li-metal batteries that use composite separators and composite electrolytes based on MOFs. The growth of Li dendrites can be inhibited and the Li-ion conduction rate can be increased by exploiting the periodic porous structures, OMSs, and adjustable molecular-level chemical compositions of MOFs. For example, Zhou et al. used a porous MOF (HKUST-1) in a pristine liquid electrolyte to stabilize a Li-metal anode (Fig. 11d) [108]. HKUST-1 has a window of 8 Å, which is close to the diameter of bistriflimide ions (TFSI−, 7.9 Å). Therefore, the 3D MOF structure formed a bottleneck, which prevented the free transmission of TFSI− owing to the spatial restriction effect of the Å-scale pores. Consequently, the MOF-modified electrolyte facilitated the free movement of lithium ions with a high migration rate and “caged’’ the TFSI− (Fig. 11e). The electrostatic attraction between the Li+ and “caged” TFSI− ions within the MOF caused the Li ions to flow homogeneously owing to the uniform distribution of TFSI− [104]. The electrochemical data (Fig. 11f) show that the overpotential of the MOF-modified electrolyte was stable, whereas the overpotential of the pristine electrolyte increased continuously during the early stages of the test. This indicates that the electrochemical processes in the MOF-modified electrolyte proceeded smoothly, whereas side reactions in the pristine electrolyte caused the battery impedance to increase. This is consistent with the analysis of the underlying mechanisms. Based on the same principles, MOFs with OMSs [109] and cationic MOFs [110] can be used as solid-state electrolytes to achieve rapid and uniform Li-ion flow by immobilizing anions through coordination and electrostatic interactions, respectively. Anionic MOFs can also conduct Li ions evenly and quickly via a hopping mechanism [111]. Furthermore, amino-functionalized MOFs coated with PP separators can be used to achieve dendrite-free Li deposition via an amino-induced uniform Li-ion flow [112]. Ionic-liquid-impregnated MOFs have also been reported as solid-state electrolytes with nanowetted interfaces [113]. The ionic liquid has high ionic conductivity and it is encapsulated in the interconnected 3D porous structure of the MOF to create an effective 3D Li+ conductive frame. In contrast to traditional solid electrolytes, which have poor interfacial contact (hard solid–solid contact interfaces), MOF-based solid electrolytes provide many soft contact sites at the atomic level between the electrolyte and the electrode via the loaded ionic liquid. Thus, a nano-wetted interface (consisting of many soft liquid–solid contact sites) is formed between the electrolyte and the cathode. A high Li-ion conduction rate and low electrolyte–electrode contact interface impedance are critical for solid Li-metal batteries [113]. 3.4 MOFs as coatings or additives to enhance the performances of LIBs In the MOF composites that we have discussed so far, such as carbon/MOF, Ni foam/MOF, and conductive polymers/MOF, MOFs have been the primary components and the primary source of electrochemical activity. This section discusses the use of MOFs as coatings or additives (with lower MOF content and varying electrochemical activities) to enhance the electrochemical properties of traditional nanomaterials. 3.4.1 MOFs as anode coating Wang et al. developed a MOF-sandwich coating for use with Si anodes [114]. The MOF films were applied to the surface of the Si layer by casting. First, Super P was spread on Cu foil, then Si particles were cast onto the Super P, and finally, ZIF-8 particles were applied on top of the silicon layer. This produced a sandwiched-Si electrode (denoted as C/Si/ZIF-8). The C/Si/ZIF-8 electrode exhibited better cycling performance than the C/Si/C and Si electrodes without casting. To systematically investigate the effects of various MOF films on the electrochemical properties of Si, a series of MOF films was prepared, including MOF-5, MIL-53, ZIF-67, HKUST-1, and NH2-MIL-53. Electrochemical characterization showed that MOFs with small windows or good flexibility had better cyclability than MOFs with an open architecture or poor flexibility. In aggregate, the C/Si/MOF electrodes performed much better than the C/Si electrodes, which was attributed to several factors. First, the MOF layers served as “cushions”, which protected the electrodes against Si volume changes. Second, the MOF layers with large pore volumes adsorbed the electrolyte, which facilitated the diffusion of Li ions. Third, the MOF coating acted like an artificial SEI film, which prevented direct contact between the electrolyte and the Si. Yu et al. produced a ZIF-8 coated TiN/Ti/Si (TiN/Ti-coated Si) nanorod composite (denoted TiN/Ti/Si/ZIF-8) in situ for use as a LIB anode [115]. In addition, Si/ZIF-8, TiN/Ti/Si, and uncoated Si were also synthesized as controls. The electrochemical impedance results showed that the charge transfer resistances R ct of the samples were ordered as follows: R ct(TiN/Ti/Si/ZIF-8) < R ct(Si/ZIF-8) < R ct(TiN/Ti/Si) < R ct(Si). Moreover, TiN/Ti/Si/ZIF-8 delivered a higher capacity and cyclability than TiN/Ti/Si. Yu et al. produced metal-organic segment (MOS)-coated Si nanorods for use as LIB anodes with the same synthesis method [116]. However, the MOS-coated uniform Si nanorods could be produced using a thinner solution and a shorter reaction time. Under the opposite reaction conditions, large ZIF-61 crystals (MOFs) formed, which did not cover the Si nanorods homogeneously. Compared to the ZIF-61 crystals, the MOSs were smaller and more amorphous. The MOS/Si electrode had a higher capacity than the ZIF-61/Si electrode, which demonstrates that a consistent and uniform coating is important for improving the electrochemical properties of electrode materials. Other similar examples of coated LIBs anodes reported in the literature include Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (HKUST-1 coated Fe3O4 microsphere) (Fig. 12 a) [117], ZnO@ZIF-8 (ZIF-8 coated ZnO nanosheet) (Fig. 12b) [118] and MnO2@ZIF-8 (ZIF-8 coated MnO2 nanorod) [118]. Each of these materials showed better electrochemical performances than their uncoated counterparts. 3.4.2 MOFs as electrode additives MOFs can also be used as additives to improve the electrochemical performance of Si. For example, Malik et al. significantly improved the cyclability of a Si anode by using UIO-67 as an additive [119]. In order to study the effects of UIO-67 on the Si anode, three control groups (UIO-66, ZrO2 and without additive) were established for comparison. The galvanostatic cycling results show that the UIO-67 additive had the greatest effect on the cycling stability of Si. The UIO-66 and ZrO2 additives had similar effects, which were smaller than that of the UIO-67 additive, although their cycling performances were far better than that of the sample with no additives. The UIO-67 additive produced the greatest improvement in the cycling performance of the Si anode, mainly because UIO-67 (4,4′-Biphenyldicarboxylic acid, H2BPDC) has a longer linker than UIO-66 (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2BDC), which makes it more flexible. The MOFs with greater flexibility can retain their porous structure when Si is alloyed/dealloyed. That is, the MOF is uniformly mixed in the Si anode and acts as a porous cushion, which stabilizes the anode during charging and discharging. Moreover, it maintains the porous structure inside the silicon electrode, which facilitates Li-ion transport. MOFs have also been studied as coating layers and additives for cathode materials. For example, Gao et al. reported that Li-rich layered oxides with MOF coatings showed higher discharge capacities under high working voltages than those without coatings (Fig. 12c) [120]. Li-rich layered oxides often work under higher voltages to achieve a higher discharge capacity, which causes structural damage to the cathode materials, such as oxygen evolution reactions. The released O2 may react with other battery components, which can degrade its performance. Thus, MOF layers on the surfaces of Li-rich layered oxides have two functions. First, they absorb the O2 released by the Li-rich layered oxides at high working voltages. Second, they stabilize the structure of the Li-rich layered oxides. Hu et al. also examined an NCM-622 LIB cathode material with a Prussian blue (PB) coating [115] et al. The NCM-622 with the PB coating showed greater capacity retention and cycling stability than the uncoated NCM-622. This is because the PB layer significantly reduced the amount of Li residues, prevented direct contact between the electrode materials and the liquid electrolytes, reduced the occurrence of side reactions, and formed a strong cathode-electrolyte interface [121]. Chae et al. researched the effects of the MOF (Co-MOF-74) as an additive on the lithium storage performance of the nickel-rich layered oxide (NCM-811) [122] (Fig. 12d). The NCM-811 cathode had poor cyclability because there were many unstable Ni4+ species on its surface, which accelerated electrolyte decomposition and the formation of nucleophilic fluoride. The electrophilic NCM-811was easily attacked by the nucleophilic F−, resulting in the NCM-811 to dissolve in the electrolyte. However, the Co-MOF-74 additive enriched Ni4+ in its pores, which prevented side reactions, the dissolution of NCM-811, electrolyte decomposition, and graphite destruction. Therefore, the NCM-811 electrode with the MOF additive exhibited excellent electrochemical properties compared to the additive-free NCM-811 electrode [122]. UIO-66, which has a similar mechanism of action, has also been tested as an additive to improve the electrochemical properties of NCM-811 [123]. Finally, we summarize the major events in the application of MOFs in LIBs and provide directions for MOFs to strive in the future (Fig. 13 ). 4 Summary and outlook There have been significant advancements in LIBs since they were first commercialized for use in portable devices and electric vehicles. However, collaborative development of electrode materials, separators, and electrolytes is necessary to improve the energy and power densities of LIBs. MOFs have attracted widespread attention in the field of LIBs owing to their large specific surface areas, well-defined and adjustable porous structures, multitudinous ligands, and OMSs. This review has discussed the latest research on MOFs and MOF composites for use in LIBs including MOFs as the primary materials (anodes, cathodes, separators, and electrolytes) and auxiliary materials (coating layers and additives for electrodes). The key details are as follows. (1) MOFs for anode materials: MOF-177 was the first MOF used as an anode material; however, it was bulky and had a single Li-storage site. By changing the metal nodes, organic linkers, and Li-storage sites, the specific capacities of MOF anodes can be improved. Compared with their bulk phases, nanoscale MOFs expose more Li-storage sites, reduce the diffusion distance for Li+ and e− in the active material, and greatly improve the reaction kinetics of LIBs. Nanoscale MOFs can be combined with conductive materials to inhibit agglomeration and considerably improve the conductivity. This is extremely valuable for LIBs with high capacities, cycling stabilities, and rates. Longer ligands and stronger coordination bonds are beneficial to increase lithium storage capacity and improve Li+ transport kinetics. The internal pores of insertion-type MOF electrodes are also crucial for improving the Li-ion storage capacity. (2) MOFs for cathode materials: MOFs with organic ligands and metal sites that can contribute to Li storage are preferred because such MOFs can considerably enhance the specific capacity. Using farther-ahead (3d) transition metals to construct MOFs can improve the electrochemical stability of MOFs, owing to the formation of strong coordination bonds. This is necessary to allow MOFs to store more Li without structural damage. (3) MOFs for separators and electrolytes: MOFs are promising materials for fabricating separators and electrolytes owing to their poor electrical conductivities, tunable porosities, high pore volumes, controllable molecular-level structures, and OMSs. Compared to traditional separators, MOF separators have a strong adsorption capacity for electrolytes, which is beneficial for Li-ion conduction. In addition, MOF-based separators with specific pore sizes can be used in dual-electrolyte batteries, which require high output voltages. MOFs containing OMSs can immobilize anions in the electrolyte, which can improve the migration of Li ions and facilitate a uniform Li-ion flow. The specific functional groups of the ligands in MOFs can also produce a uniform Li-ion flow owing to certain chemical interactions with the Li ions. MOFs containing OMSs and cationic frames can also be used to immobilize anions in solid electrolytes to improve the Li-ion conduction rate. (4) MOFs as coatings and additives for electrodes: Despite their poor conductivity, MOFs can improve the electrochemical performance of electrode materials when they are used as protective layers or additives. There are several reasons for this. First, the large pore volumes of MOFs allow them to adsorb electrolytes, which facilitates the diffusion of Li+. Second, MOF coatings can act as artificial SEI films, which prevent direct contact between the electrolytes and the electrode materials. Third, MOFs with high flexibility can be used as additives where the electrode materials undergo large volume changes during charging and discharging. This helps to maintain the porous structure inside the electrode, which is required for Li-ion transport. Fourth, when MOFs are used as additives, they can absorb the substances released by the electrode materials during operation, such as O2 and high-valence metal ions, which can negatively affect the performance of the battery. In experiments, pristine MOFs and MOF composites have shown promising developments in the field of LIBs and they have great potential. For practical applications, the stability of MOFs should be prioritized, particularly in terms of water, air, acid, and base stability. Although there are thousands of different MOFs, most exhibit poor stability under these conditions, which can be extremely detrimental to chemical batteries. Therefore, efforts should be focused on enhancing the chemical durability of existing MOFs and synthesizing new MOFs with high chemical stability. Currently, the methods used to synthesize MOFs are time-consuming, energy-intensive, and require expensive raw materials. Therefore, it is important to develop relatively simple MOF-synthesis technologies and to encourage the preparation of battery materials with good electrochemical properties using inexpensive MOFs. Electrical conductivity is the greatest obstacle to the practical application of MOFs as electrode materials. MOFs with good conductivities have been reported; however, their high cost and low yield make them unsuitable for practical applications. Combining MOFs with conductive materials (such as carbon, metal-based materials, and conductive polymers) may be an effective way to enhance their conductivity. However, many MOFs are destroyed or become inhomogeneous when combined with other materials, and only a few are suitable for such treatments. Therefore, effective and practical methods of combining MOFs with conductive materials must be developed. On the side, MOFs have ultra-high specific surface area and pore volume, which indicates that MOFs have low tap density, which is not conducive to the improvement of volume energy density as electrode materials. How to solve the problem of low tap density of MOFs is also an obstacle to the commercialization of MOFs electrodes. Currently, the lithium storage mechanisms of MOFs are still obscure. So as to systematically study the lithium storage mechanism of MOFs, advanced characterization methods and theoretical calculations are needed. In addition, MOFs with the isostructural or same configuration should be more synthesized to study their electrochemical differences and analyze the changes in electrochemical properties caused by changes in metal centers or ligands, which is extremely beneficial for us to understand the lithium storage mechanism of MOFs. For example, the research conducted by Cheng [17,18] and Zou [125] on the lithium storage performance of MOFs with the same configuration is highly valuable. Overall, MOFs have great potential for use as separators and electrolytes. This is because they do not require high conductivities or electrochemical activities. MOF has a high specific surface area and pore volume, and has a good adsorption ability for liquid electrolytes and ionic liquids. In addition, the large pore volume can also load lithium salts, which provides the possibility for LIBs to achieve semi-solid or all-solid. However, the brittleness and instability of MOFs may hinder their widespread use in these applications. Therefore, MOF film-forming technologies should be developed as a prerequisite for their use as separators and electrolytes. Cheng-cai Liu received his M.S. degree in chemistry from Nankai University (NKU) in 2019. He is currently a Ph.D. student under the guidance of Prof. Bo-Rong Wu at Beijing Institute of Technology (BIT). His research work is focused on the development of metal-organic-framework-based materials (MOFs) for Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and lithium metal batteries (LMBs). Borong Wu is currently a full professor at School of Material Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology. His researches focus on new energy materials and energy storage devices, mainly including lithium-ion batteries, NiH battery, super capacitor and other new energy storage devices and related key materials. Tao Liu received his M.S. degree in Materials Science and Engineering from Beijing Institute of Technology under the supervision of Prof. Borong Wu in 2023. Currently, his research interests include the electrode materials for Li-ion batteries. Yuanxing Zhang is currently studying for a doctorate at the School of Materials Science, Beijing Institute of Technology. His research direction focuses on pre-lithiation of silicon anodes and interface modification of polymer solid electrolytes. Jingwen Cui entered Beijing Institute of Technology to study for a master's degree in 2022. Currently, under the guidance of Prof. Borong, her research includes polymer solid electrolyte and halide solid electrolytes for Li-ion batteries. Lingjun Huang received his B.S. degree in New Energy Materials and Devices from Beijing Institute of Technology under the supervision of Prof. Borong Wu in 2023. Currently, his research interests include metal-organic-framework-based materials for Li-ion batteries. Guo-qiang Tan received his B.S. degree from Hunan University in 2007 and his Ph.D. degree from Beijing Institute of Technology in 2014. After that, he started his postdoctoral work at Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) and University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). From 2019, he joined the Beijing Institute of Technology as a full-time professor. His research focus on Lithium-Sulfur batteries, Li-Air batteries, Solid-State electrolytes, Lithium anodes, etc. Ling Zhang received her PhD degree from Beijing Institute of Technology in 2021, and continued her post-doctoral research at Chongqing Innovation Center of Beijing Institute of Technology. Her research interests include the key electrode materials and the solid-state electrolytes for lithium-sulfur and Li-ion batteries. Yuefeng Su is currently a full professor at Scholol of Material Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology. He primarily conducts research on environmentally-friendly secondary batteries and advanced energy materials. His research interests revolve around developing new cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries and high energy density smart secondary batteries. Feng Wu is academician of Chinese Academy of Engineering, academician of International Eurasian Academy of Sciences, academician of Asia-Pacific Academy of Materials Science, and distinguished professor of Beijing Institute of Technology. His researches are related to new secondary batteries and energy storage materials.

coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are among the most promising materials for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) owing to their high surface area, periodic porosity, adjustable pore size, and controllable chemical composition. For instance, their unique porous structures promote electrolyte penetration, ions transport, and make them ideal for battery separators. Regulating the chemical composition of MOF can introduce more active sites for electrochemical reactions. Therefore, MOFs and their related composites have been extensively and thoroughly explored for LIBs. However, the reported reviews solely include the applications of MOFs in the electrode materials of LIBs and rarely involve other aspects. A systematic review of the application of MOFs in LIBs is essential for understanding the mechanism of MOFs and better designing related MOFs battery materials. This review systematically evaluates the latest developments in pristine MOFs and MOF composites for LIB applications, including MOFs as the main materials (anode, cathode, separators, and electrolytes) to auxiliary materials (coating layers and additives for electrodes). Furthermore, the synthesis, modification methods, challenges, and prospects for the application of MOFs in LIBs are discussed.
